    limpiar_intro

    limpiar_intro.Rmd

    What is LimpiaR?

    Primarily a library for cleaning messy text-data, such as that which comes from social media or reviews. This type of data is â€˜messyâ€™, because users often write in slang, abbreviations, emojis & orthographical errors.

    In its initial release, LimpiaR is focused around the Spanish language, but some of its functions are language-ambivalent. In the future, LimpiaR will be updated to cover English, and perhaps other languages.

    For non-Spanish speakers, limpiar is a Spanish verb, which translates in English to â€˜to cleanâ€™. So generally, when youâ€™re calling a LimpiaR function, like limpiar_accents(), you can think of it as clean_accents().

    Loading Everything Into R

    library(magrittr)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(stringr)
library(LimpiaR)

#library(tidyverse)

    Productivity tip for those of you who are just setting out on your programming/R journey: all of LimpiaRâ€™s functions begin with limpiar_, and once the library has been loaded if you type limpiar_ in an Rstudio script or Rmarkdown codeblock, youâ€™ll get a drop down menu of all LimpiaR functions, so you donâ€™t need to remember the names of all of them.

    data
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
#>    Mention.Content                                           Mention.Url

#>  1 "holaaaaaa! cÃ³Ã³mo    estÃ¡s @magdalena   ?!"               www.twitter.com/poâ€¦

    We created a data frame which contains some posts and URLs. After loading libraries and data, the first part of any workflow should be to clean up the data frameâ€™s names, this makes using tab completion, and accessing column names much faster (which in the long run = big productivity gains). For this, weâ€™ll use the janitor package. You can uncomment the code to install janitor if it is not already installed on your machine.

    # ifelse(!"janitor" %in% installed.packages(),
#    install.packages("janitor"), library(janitor))

(data <- data %>% 
   janitor::clean_names())
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
#>    mention_content                                           mention_url        
#>    <chr>                                                     <chr>              
#>  1 "holaaaaaa! cÃ³Ã³mo    estÃ¡s @magdalena   ?!"               www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror! https://guardiaâ€¦ www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #â€¦ www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                  www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  5 "RT dale un click a ver una mujer baila con su perro"     www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  6 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  7 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "            www.instagram.com/â€¦
#>  8 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  9 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 10 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦

    For most workflows, the next step will be to make the text variable all lower case. You do not need a LimpiaR function for this, as the base R function tolower() works just fine.

    data %>%
  mutate(mention_content = tolower(mention_content))
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
#>    mention_content                                           mention_url        
#>    <chr>                                                     <chr>              
#>  1 "holaaaaaa! cÃ³Ã³mo    estÃ¡s @magdalena   ?!"               www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  2 "  han visto este articulo!? que horror! https://guardiaâ€¦ www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #â€¦ www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                  www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  5 "rt dale un click a ver una mujer baila con su perro"     www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  6 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  7 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "            www.instagram.com/â€¦
#>  8 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  9 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 10 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦

    We did not assign the changes, so whilst they did print to the console, the data object was not actually changed, and the text variable is not currently in lower case.

    LimpiaRâ€™s Functions

    limpiar_accents()

    Now weâ€™re going to look at LimpiaRâ€™s functions individually. The first function is limpiar_accents, this will remove Spanish accents from the text variable. We will use the assignment operator to make sure these changes are saved. You can type ?limpiar_accents (or ?any_function) to access the documentation, and see which arguments you need to fill in.

    (data <- data %>%
  limpiar_accents(text_var = mention_content))
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
#>    mention_content                                           mention_url        
#>    <chr>                                                     <chr>              
#>  1 "holaaaaaa! coomo    estas @magdalena   ?!"               www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror! https://guardiaâ€¦ www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #â€¦ www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                  www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  5 "RT dale un click a ver una mujer baila con su perro"     www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  6 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  7 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "            www.instagram.com/â€¦
#>  8 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  9 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 10 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦

    limpiar_duplicates()

    Now weâ€™ll remove duplicate posts, notice that we donâ€™t actually need to type text_var = mention_content, because the default argument for text_var is already mention_content. Note: If the text column in our data frame were called â€˜textâ€™ we would have to specify text_var = text.

    (data <- data %>%
  limpiar_duplicates())
#> # A tibble: 7 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 "holaaaaaa! coomo    estas @magdalena   ?!"                www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror! https://guardianâ€¦ www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #pâ€¦ www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                   www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 5 "RT dale un click a ver una mujer baila con su perro"      www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 6 "grax ntonces q?"                                          www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 7 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "             www.instagram.com/â€¦

    limpiar_retweets

    If you need to remove retweets, for example to create a bigram network, limpiar has a function just for that.

    (data <- data %>%
   limpiar_retweets())
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 "holaaaaaa! coomo    estas @magdalena   ?!"                www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror! https://guardianâ€¦ www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #pâ€¦ www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                   www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 5 "grax ntonces q?"                                          www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 6 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "             www.instagram.com/â€¦

    limpiar_url

    We generally donâ€™t want URLs appearing in our charts or analyses, so we can remove them with the limpiar_url function.

    (data <- data %>%
   limpiar_url)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                                   mention_url 
#>   <chr>                                                             <chr>       
#> 1 "holaaaaaa! coomo    estas @magdalena   ?!"                       www.twitterâ€¦
#> 2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror!  NO SE PUEDE!!"          www.twitterâ€¦
#> 3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #porfavor" www.facebooâ€¦
#> 4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                          www.facebooâ€¦
#> 5 "grax ntonces q?"                                                 www.youtubeâ€¦
#> 6 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "                    www.instagrâ€¦

    limpiar_spaces

    Next weâ€™ll look at how to use LimpiaR to remove annoying white spaces, like those at the beginning of a sentence, or between punctuation, or multiple white spaces for no reason; as is common in the messy data we often encounter.

    (data <- data %>%
  limpiar_spaces())
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                               mention_url     
#>   <chr>                                                         <chr>           
#> 1 holaaaaaa! coomo estas @magdalena ?!                          www.twitter.comâ€¦
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!           www.twitter.comâ€¦
#> 3 ayyyyyy a mi me gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #porfavor www.facebook.coâ€¦
#> 4 jajajajaja eres un wn!                                        www.facebook.coâ€¦
#> 5 grax ntonces q?                                               www.youtube.comâ€¦
#> 6 yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£                   www.instagram.câ€¦

    limpiar_tags

    We can also remove user handles (e.g. @magdalena) and hashtags with the limpiar_tags function. Remember, you can type ?limpiar_tags to access documentation.

    Replace only hashtags:

    data %>%
  limpiar_tags(user = FALSE, hashtag = TRUE)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 holaaaaaa! coomo estas @magdalena ?!                       www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!        www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 3 ayyyyyy a mi me gustaria ir a londres yaaa hashtag hashtag www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 4 jajajajaja eres un wn!                                     www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 5 grax ntonces q?                                            www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 6 yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£                www.instagram.com/â€¦

    Replace only user tags:

    data %>%
  limpiar_tags(user = TRUE, hashtag = FALSE)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                               mention_url     
#>   <chr>                                                         <chr>           
#> 1 holaaaaaa! coomo estas @user ?!                               www.twitter.comâ€¦
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!           www.twitter.comâ€¦
#> 3 ayyyyyy a mi me gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #porfavor www.facebook.coâ€¦
#> 4 jajajajaja eres un wn!                                        www.facebook.coâ€¦
#> 5 grax ntonces q?                                               www.youtube.comâ€¦
#> 6 yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£                   www.instagram.câ€¦

    Replace both hashtags and user handles:

    data %>%
  limpiar_tags()
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 holaaaaaa! coomo estas @user ?!                            www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!        www.twitter.com/poâ€¦

    Quick recap before the next session. Weâ€™ve looked at: cleaning column names with janitor::clean_names() making the text variable lower case with mutate() & tolower() cleaning accents with limpiar_accents() cleaning duplicate posts with limpiar_duplicates() cleaning retweets with limpiar_retweets() cleaning urls with limpiar_url() cleaning spaces with limpiar_spaces()

    limpiar_shorthands

    One of the biggest problems with the messy data we encounter, are shorthands. Generally, algorithms have been trained on clean, standard language, so they do not encounter shorthands and abbreviations. Shorthands also change all the time, making it impractical to continuously train algorithms as new shorthands arise. This function attempts to bridge that gap, by normalising the most common shorthands.

    (data <- data %>%
   limpiar_shorthands())
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                               mention_url     
#>   <chr>                                                         <chr>           
#> 1 holaaaaaa! coomo estas @magdalena ?!                          www.twitter.comâ€¦
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!           www.twitter.comâ€¦
#> 3 ayyyyyy a mi me gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #porfavor www.facebook.coâ€¦
#> 4 jajajajaja eres un wuevon!                                    www.facebook.coâ€¦
#> 5 gracias entonces que?                                         www.youtube.comâ€¦
#> 6 yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£                   www.instagram.câ€¦

    limpiar_repeated_chars

    We donâ€™t want our algorithm to have to learn the difference between â€˜ajajajâ€™ and â€˜jajaâ€™ or â€˜ayâ€™ and â€˜ayyyyâ€™ as practically speaking, there is none. We also donâ€™t want to introduce unnecessary tokens, so we normalise the most common occurrences of repeated or additional characters.

    (data <- data %>%
   limpiar_repeat_chars())
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                        mention_url            
#>   <chr>                                                  <chr>                  
#> 1 hola! como estas @magdalena ?!                         www.twitter.com/post1  
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!    www.twitter.com/post2  
#> 3 ay a mi me gustaria ir a londres ya #llevame #porfavor www.facebook.com/post1 
#> 4 jaja eres un wuevon!                                   www.facebook.com/post2 
#> 5 gracias entonces que?                                  www.youtube.com/post1  
#> 6 yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£            www.instagram.com/post1

    Generally, the steps weâ€™ve taken so far will be used in each and every analysis/project to help clean the data. We will now look at some of the more circumstantial functions, i.e.Â they will not be used in every analysis.

    limpiar_emojis

    We donâ€™t need to use limpiar_emojis for every analysis, as many ParseR & SegmentR functions ignore them implicitly. However, if we know that we need to for a special purpose, we can can use limpiar_emojis(). One problem with this, and the reason it is for special cases only, is the emojiâ€™s encodings are in English. We may, at some point, translate them to Spanish, but it seems unlikely.

    data %>%
  limpiar_emojis(text_var = mention_content, with_emoji_tag =  FALSE)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 "hola! como estas @magdalena ?!"                           www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 "han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!"      www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 3 "ay a mi me gustaria ir a londres ya #llevame #porfavor"   www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 4 "jaja eres un wuevon!"                                     www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 5 "gracias entonces que?"                                    www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 6 "yo soy el mejor face with tears of joy face with tears oâ€¦ www.instagram.com/â€¦

    or with the default settings:

    data %>%
  limpiar_emojis()
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 "hola! como estas @magdalena ?!"                           www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 "han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!"      www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 3 "ay a mi me gustaria ir a londres ya #llevame #porfavor"   www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 4 "jaja eres un wuevon!"                                     www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 5 "gracias entonces que?"                                    www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 6 "yo soy el mejor face_with_tears_of_joy_emoji face_with_tâ€¦ www.instagram.com/â€¦

    ##limpiar_stopwords Stop words are common words that do not provide us with much information as to an utteranceâ€™s meaning. For example, in the sentence: â€˜the man is in prison for theftâ€™, if we knew only one word from this sentence, and that word was â€˜isâ€™, â€˜inâ€™, â€˜theâ€™, or â€˜forâ€™ then we wouldnâ€™t have much idea what the sentence is about. However, â€˜prisonâ€™ or â€˜theftâ€™, would give us a lot more information.

    For many analyses, we remove stop words to help us see the â€˜highest informationâ€™ words, to get a high-level understanding of large bodies of texts (such as in topic modelling and bigram networks.) For virtually all scenarios, you will want to use the limpiar_stopwords() with the argument stop_words = â€œtopicsâ€ like so:

    data %>%
  limpiar_stopwords(stop_words = "topics") %>%
  limpiar_spaces() #to clear the spaces of words that were removed
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                            mention_url            
#>   <chr>                                      <chr>                  
#> 1 hola! @magdalena ?!                        www.twitter.com/post1  
#> 2 visto articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!! www.twitter.com/post2  
#> 3 ay gustaria londres #llevame #porfavor     www.facebook.com/post1 
#> 4 jaja wuevon!                               www.facebook.com/post2 
#> 5 gracias ?                                  www.youtube.com/post1  
#> 6 ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚,!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£                             www.instagram.com/post1

    Sentences can look quite strange without stopwords, and a lot of social posts are virtually meaningless. Itâ€™s also worth pointing out, that a lot of information can be lost when removing stop words. Many phrases in English and Spanish have very different meanings when a stop word is removed.

    Utility Functions

    We are nearly at the end of this introduction to LimpiaR, but before we finish, letâ€™s look at two utility functions which may be useful. Weâ€™ve conjoured up a new data frame called df, which we will use to show the last two functions and how to chain everything together.

    df
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 3
#>    mention_content                                      mention_url       na_col
#>    <chr>                                                <chr>             <chr> 
#>  1 "holaaaaaa! cÃ³Ã³mo    estÃ¡s @magdalena   ?!"          www.twitter.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#>  2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror! https://guâ€¦ www.twitter.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#>  3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevâ€¦ www.facebook.comâ€¦ <NA>  
#>  4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                             www.facebook.comâ€¦ <NA>  
#>  5 "RT dale un click a ver una mujer baila con su perrâ€¦ www.twitter.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#>  6 "grax ntonces q?"                                    www.youtube.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#>  7 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "       www.instagram.coâ€¦ <NA>  
#>  8 "grax ntonces q?"                                    www.youtube.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#>  9 "grax ntonces q?"                                    www.youtube.com/â€¦ tadaa 
#> 10 "grax ntonces q?"                                    www.youtube.com/â€¦ <NA>

    limpiar_inpsect

    So, imagine that we see a strange pattern, and we want to check whatâ€™s going on with that specific pattern. We can use limpiar_inspect to view all posts which contain that pattern in an interactive frame!

    limpiar_inspect(df, pattern = "ntonces", text_var = mention_content,
                post_url = mention_url, title = "ntonces")

    Whilst itâ€™s pretty obvious that all of the â€˜grax ntonces q?â€™ posts are exactly the same, in the real world weâ€™re going to have 10,000 times as many posts, and searching for suspicious patterns will take up a lot of our time.

    limpiar_na_cols

    This final function is useful when we want to remove â€˜mostly NAâ€™ columns of a data frame. We may want to do this to save memory, for example if we have 400,000 posts and 80 columns. In this case weâ€™ll get rid of all columns for which 25% or more of their values are NA.

    limpiar_na_cols(df,threshold =  0.25)
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
#>    mention_content                                           mention_url        
#>    <chr>                                                     <chr>              
#>  1 "holaaaaaa! cÃ³Ã³mo    estÃ¡s @magdalena   ?!"               www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  2 "  han visto este articulo!? Que horror! https://guardiaâ€¦ www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  3 "ayyyyyy a mi me   gustaria ir a londres yaaa #llevame #â€¦ www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  4 "jajajajaja eres un wn!"                                  www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#>  5 "RT dale un click a ver una mujer baila con su perro"     www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#>  6 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  7 "yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚, no eres nada!! ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ "            www.instagram.com/â€¦
#>  8 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#>  9 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 10 "grax ntonces q?"                                         www.youtube.com/poâ€¦

    Putting It All Together

    To speed things up, we can call the functions together in one big long pipe.

    df %>%
  limpiar_na_cols(threshold = 0.25)%>%
  limpiar_accents()%>%
  limpiar_retweets()%>%
  limpiar_shorthands()%>%
  limpiar_repeat_chars()%>%
  limpiar_url()%>%
  limpiar_emojis()%>%
  limpiar_shorthands()%>%
  limpiar_spaces()%>%
  limpiar_duplicates()
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   mention_content                                            mention_url        
#>   <chr>                                                      <chr>              
#> 1 hola! como estas @magdalena ?!                             www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 2 han visto este articulo!? Que horror! NO SE PUEDE!!        www.twitter.com/poâ€¦
#> 3 ay a mi me gustaria ir a londres ya #llevame #porfavor     www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 4 jaja eres un wuevon!                                       www.facebook.com/pâ€¦
#> 5 gracias entonces que?                                      www.youtube.com/poâ€¦
#> 6 yo soy el mejor face_with_tears_of_joy_emoji face_with_teâ€¦ www.instagram.com/â€¦

    However, on very large data frames, it will often be better to prioritise one, or a few functions at a time, assigning your data frame as you go.

    Bonus Function

    Once youâ€™re familiar with how LimpiaR works, you may want to use a bonus function, limpiar_df to do a bunch of things at once and speed everything up. limpiar_df also has an option to remove punctuation!

    limpiar_df(df, text_var = mention_content, remove_punctuation = TRUE)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
#>   mention_content                                      mention_url        na_col
#>   <chr>                                                <chr>              <chr> 
#> 1 hola como estas magdalena                            www.twitter.com/pâ€¦ <NA>  
#> 2 han visto este articulo que horror no se puede       www.twitter.com/pâ€¦ <NA>  
#> 3 ay a mi me gustaria ir a londres ya llevame porfavor www.facebook.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#> 4 jaja eres un wuevon                                  www.facebook.com/â€¦ <NA>  
#> 5 gracias entonces que                                 www.youtube.com/pâ€¦ <NA>  
#> 6 yo soy el mejor ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ no eres nada ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£             www.instagram.comâ€¦ <NA>

    If you wanted to, you could pipe in limpiar_na_cols, limpiar_emojis (or any other pipeable function!).
